Each system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped through a series of liquid feed solenoid valves, an expansion valve, and into a liquid recirculator. From there, low pressure liquid is pumped to each evaporator, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve and into each evaporator. Low temperature liquid circulates through each evaporator. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which passes through an isolation valve and is returned to the liquid recirculator. The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the recirculator and the gas is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.

1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Wonderful Citrus has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 Wonderful Citrus, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Wonderful Citrus has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name                 | Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)
NER - Cold Storage             Anhydrous Ammonia                13,000
SER - Degreening               Anhydrous Ammonia                11,000
NWER - Cold Storage            Anhydrous Ammonia                15,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and pro

cedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Descriptions

Wonderful Citrus D1 operates a commercial cold storage for a variety of citrus products in Delano, CA. The facility has three ammonia refrigeration systems that provide refrigeration capacity to the following:

Process 1 - North Machinery Room
(3) Storage Rooms
(1) Loading Dock

Process 2 - South Machinery Room
(1) Plate Heat Exchanger (to chill Glycol)

Process 3 - Northwest Machinery Room
(1) Storage Room
(1) Packaging Room

Process 1 and 3 are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and a liquid recirculator as required for a pumped overfeed operation. Process 2 is equipped with a plate heat exchanger and liquid recirculator as required for a pumped overfeed operation.

Process 1 and 3 control valve groups are located on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly above each machinery room. A partial list of system components includes:

ract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, Wonderful Citrus now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a living document. It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Wonderful Citrus employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Wonderful Citrus will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.

ts have occurred:

2012/2013 - American Inc. renovated the computer control system for Process 1 and 2.
2012 - American Inc. installed new evaporative condensers on Process 1 and 2.
2012 - American Inc. installed a new high pressure receiver, screw compressor, storage room, and loading dock on Process 1.
2013-2014 - American Inc. installed Process 3 Northwest Machinery Room at Wonderful Citrus D1, which provides refrigeration capacity to Room 4 and Packaging Room. 

Each system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to each diffusion tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. 

There are two ammonia detectors installed inside each refrigeration machinery room. One sensor is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate the mechanical ventilation system at a normal rate of 20 air changes per hour and activate an audible alarm and strobe. The second sensor is set at 15,000 ppm, which will shut down all refrigeration machinery inside the refrigeration machinery room and activate an audible alarm and strobe. Each refrigerated area has a standalone detector that is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate an audible alarm and strobe.

An emergency control box is installed on the exterior wall of Process 1 and 2 machinery rooms, which contain three valves. The high and low side of the system each have a valve that would discharge to each diffusion tank. The connecting pipe between the high and low side has one equalizer valve that would equalize the system. Process 3 is equipped with an emergency pressure control system, which provides means of internally mitigating an overpressure event. 

Each ammonia refrigeration system at Wonderful Citrus D1 consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by

piping, but are not connected nor co-located relative to each other. As such, each refrigeration system at Wonderful Citrus D1 is treated as a single process.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Wonderful Citrus has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration processes at the Wonderful Citrus facility are an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia processes contains a total charge of approximately 39,000 (LBS). It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History

Wonderful Citrus has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

Wonderful Citrus' emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
- California Emergency Action Plan

- Title 8 CCR §3220
- Federal Emergency Action Plan - Title 29 CFR §1910.38 
- California Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 §5192(q)
- Federal Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR §1910.120(q)

Strategically, we will respond minimally to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Wonderful Citrus has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Wonderful Citrus continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Wonderful Citrus' ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Wonderful Citrus' management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.
Wonderful Citrus has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.
